Fig. 1 Illustration of the Ru(OH)x-catalyzed alcohol oxidation mechanism. (a) Conventional Ru-H induced β-H elimination, (b) Free-radical induced β-H Elimination proposed in this work. Fig. 2 Catalytic oxidation of PPol Over Various Ru(OH)x catalysts. Reaction conditions: 200 mg PPol, 25 mg catalyst, 10 mL toluene/H2O, 2 bar of O2, 100 °C, 10 h. Fig. 3 Oxidation of PPol over various catalysts. (a) The conductivity of different carbon supports and their promotion effects on Ru(OH)x in the oxidation of PPol. The conductivity is taken from the value at 30 MPa pressure. (b) Recyclability of Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst. Reaction conditions: 200 mg PPol, 25 mg catalyst, 75 mg NaOH, 10 mL H2O, 5 bar of O2, 120 °C, 1 h. Fig. 4 TEM and XPS analysis of Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst. (a–-b) TEM and HRTEM images; (c–g) STEM and corresponding EDS mapping images; (h) Ru 3p XPS spectrum; (i) O 1s XPS spectrum; (j) C 1s XPS spectrum. Fig. 5 Atomic force microscopy of Ru(OH)x/Cs-700. (a) Topographic image; (b) KPFM surface potential map; (c) CPD changes along the lines marked A1-A3; (d) Schematic of Ru(OH)x and carbon band profiles. Fig. 6 Electron transfer testes of RuO2 with different supports. (a) Schematic diagram of the experimental setup; (b) Current density generated with the switching of atmosphere. Reaction conditions: 0.1 M NaOH, 0.02 M HMF, 100 ml H2O, Cs-700/SiO2/Al2O3/TiO2 (working electrode) and RuO2·xH2O (counter electrode), 40 °C, N2 or O2 was flushed at a flow rate of 50 ml/min. Fig. 7 Mechanistic studies. (a) Free radical scavenging experiments, Reaction conditions: 200 mg PPol, 25 mg catalyst, 75 mg scavenger, 10 ml H2O, 5 bar O2, 120 °C, 2 h; (b) EPR analysis with DMPO as trapping agent in methanol; (c-d) Transfer hydrogenation of acetophenone by isopropanol Over Different Ru(OH)x catalysts, Reaction conditions: 200 mg acetophenone, 50 mg catalyst, 10 mL solvent, 5 bar N2, 120 °C, 12 h. Fig. 8 Proposed free-radical induced β-H elimination mechanism over Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst in aqueous phase. Fig. 9 Oxidative depolymerization of native poplar wood. Reaction conditions: 500 mg poplar biomass, 10 mL of 1 M NaOH aqueous solution, 50 mg catalyst, 160 °C, 2 h, 20 bar air. Catalytic oxidative depolymerization of lignin is an important strategy for producing valuable oxygen-functionalized monoaromatic compounds. However, this process is less efficient over heterogeneous catalysts due to the slow rate-determining step of selective oxidation of secondary alcohol (Cα-OH to Cα=O) in β-O-4 lignin linkages. Herein, a facile and efficient Ru(OH)x/C catalyst was developed for the oxidative depolymerization of lignin model compounds and real lignin in aqueous phase using molecular oxygen as oxidant. Extensive characterizations revealed that molecular oxygen abstracts electrons from the conductive carbon matrix to generate superoxide radicals (•O2 –), which are subsequently converted to hydroperoxide radicals (HOO•) in the presence of water. The Cα-OH in the β-O-4 linkages first reacts with Ru-OH to form a Ru-O-C(H)- metal alkoxide intermediate, which then undergoes β-H elimination with the help of HOO• to generate H2O2 and surface Ru-O-C•- species. Hydrolysis of Ru-O-C•- leads to the generation of Cα=O products and the regeneration of Ru-OH sites. Different from the traditional Ru(OH)x-catalyzed alcohol dehydration mechanism in which Ru abstracts β-H to form Ru-H, in this case, the β-H in the Ru-alkoxide intermediate is eliminated by the hydroperoxide radicals rather than Ru, avoiding the formation of inert Ru-H species, thereby accelerating the dehydrogenation of Cα-OH to Cα=O. Electrochemical measurements further confirmed the charge transfer from Ru(OH)x to carbon during alcohol oxidation, demonstrating that electron donation by alcohol occurs on Ru(OH)x, while electron abstraction by O2 occurs on the carbon. The free-radical-involved β-H elimination reaction pathway endows Ru(OH)x/C with superior catalytic oxidation activity in the aqueous phase compared with traditional metal oxides supported Ru(OH)x (e.g. SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2), and provides a fundamental basis for the rational design of aqueous phase oxidation catalysts. Keywords Alcohol oxidation Ru(OH)x catalyst Lignin depolymerization Charge transfer Free-radical reactions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignocellulosic biomass, as the most abundant renewable carbon resource on the earth, has been regarded as an alternative feedstock to fossil resources in the next generation [1]. However, while the utilization of cellulose and hemicellulose fractions in lignocellulosic biomass has been well-established for the preparation of chemicals and materials, as the second part of lignocellulose, lignin remains difficult to produce valuable products and is always burned to provide energy in biorefineries [2,3]. Lignin is composed of phenylpropane units connected by various C-O and CC linkages (e.g. β-O-4, β-1, β-β, 4-O-5) and is the only abundant natural resource of aromatic compounds [4]. Therefore, the high-value utilization of lignin to produce aromatic chemicals constitutes a cutting-edge frontier within the field of biomass chemistry [5]. In terms of the various linkages in lignin, β-O-4 linkages with Cα-OH moieties account for approximately 43 % to 65 % of all linkages in the natural lignin of softwood and hardwood [6]. Numerous catalytic processes, including hydrogenolysis, pyrolysis hydrolysis and oxidation have been reported for the efficient depolymerization of lignin into monoaromatic compounds by selective cleavage of β-O-4 linkages [7–10]. Recently, oxidative cleavage of β-O-4 linkages of lignin has attracted great attentions due to its ability to produce oxygen-functionalized aromatic products such as phenols, aromatic acids and ketones [11]. For example, Stahl et al. have reported formic acid-induced depolymerization of lignin involves the first oxidation of Cα-OH to Cα=O in β-O-4 linkages of lignin by stoichiometric oxidants (4-acetamido-TEMPO/HCl/HNO3 system), followed by depolymerization of oxidized lignin under mild conditions in formic acid solutions [12]. Wang et al. reported a combination of VOSO4/TEMPO and Cu/1,10-phenanthroline catalytic system for a two-step oxidative cleavage of lignin to produce aromatic acids and phenols [13]. Zhang et. al reported a CuCl/NaOH catalytic system for the oxidative cleavage of β-O-4 linkages in lignin to form aromatic acids and phenols with air as the oxidant in aqueous phase [14]. Although homogeneous catalytic systems with stoichiometric oxidants and molecular catalysts exhibit high lignin depolymerization efficiency, the high cost and separation issues may be obstacles to their application [15]. Oxidative depolymerization of lignin using molecular oxygen as oxidant and water as solvent over heterogeneous catalysts is an environmentally friendly strategy that is highly desirable for lignin biorefining. Previous studies have shown that pre-oxidation of the secondary alcohol (Cα-OH) in the β-O-4 linkages to Cα=O can apparently reduce the binding energy of the adjacent Cα-Cβ bond and promote its oxidative cleavage [16,17]. This reaction step is the key step in the oxidative depolymerization of lignin into aromatic acids and phenols under mild reaction conditions. Indeed, the selective oxidation of secondary alcohols to the corresponding ketones via heterogeneous catalysis is of great significance in organic synthesis [18,19]. Based on this knowledge, metal catalysts for alcohol oxidations, such as Pd and Au, have been reported for the oxidative depolymerization of lignin and its model compounds. For example, Pd/CeO2 catalysts have been employed for the oxidative cleavage of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (β-O-4 lignin model compound) and organosolv lignin in the presence of O2. It has been demonstrated that Pd nanoparticles play a crucial role in the oxidation of Cα-OH to Cα=O in β-O-4 lignin linkages, which is a prerequisite for the subsequent cleavage of Cα-Cβ bonds [20]. Au-Pd alloy metal nanoparticles supported on covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) have been used for the cleavage of β-O-4 lignin model compounds at 160 °C and 0.5 MPa O2 in methanol solvent. Further mechanistic studies revealed that metal nanoparticles catalyzed the oxidation of Cα-OH into Cα=O, while basic CTFs promoted the cleavage of ketone compounds [21]. However, compared with homogeneous oxidation systems, the oxidative depolymerization of lignin over heterogeneous catalysts still suffers from the problem of poor monomer yield due to the low activity of oxidizing secondary Cα-OH in the β-O-4 linkages to Cα=O on supported metal catalysts. Typically, the oxidation of secondary alcohols to ketones involves the dehydrogenation of the adjacent CHOH moiety. In fact, it is much easier to eliminate α-H from OH than β-H from CH. Therefore, for alcohol oxidation reactions, β-H elimination is always the rate-determining step [22,23]. It has been reported that supported Ru(OH)x catalysts exhibit high activity for alcohol oxidation [24]. For example, Ru(OH)x supported on Al2O3 exhibited high oxidation activity towards various alcohols, even exceeding that of homogeneous Ru catalysts [25]. Mechanistically, it is generally believed that alcohol dehydrates at the Ru-OH site to form a Ru-alkoxide intermediate, eliminating α-H, and then the β-H in CH is abstracted by Ru to form a Ru-H intermediate, releasing the aldehyde/ketone product (Fig. 1 a). Finally, Ru-H is regenerated into Ru-OH by oxygen. It is worth noting that the Ru-H species is relatively inert and its oxidation to Ru-OH by molecular oxygen is slow, which limits the overall oxidation activity of alcohols over Ru(OH)x catalysts [26]. In this work, highly efficient carbon-supported Ru(OH)x catalysts were prepared for the oxidation of β-O-4 lignin model compound and authentic lignin by oxygen in the aqueous phase. It was found that carbon-supported Ru(OH)x exhibited significantly higher activity than traditional metal oxide supports such as Al2O3 and TiO2 in the catalytic oxidation of secondary alcohol Cα-OH to Cα=O. Mechanistic studies using various techniques including EPR and electrochemical tests revealed a free radical-involving alcohol oxidation reaction pathway (Fig. 1b) over Ru(OH)x/C catalyst in aqueous phase, in which β-H is eliminated by hydroperoxide radicals (HOO•) rather than Ru. The proposed free radical-induced β-H elimination pathway in the aqueous phase deepens the understanding of alcohol oxidation on metal surfaces. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials D-(+)-glucose (C6H12O6, ≥99.5 %), titanium oxide (TiO2, ≥99 %), alumina (γ-Al2O3, ≥99 %), silicon oxide (SiO2, ≥99 %), graphite (8000 mesh, ≥99.5 %), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ≥99 %), 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (C6H11NO, DMPO, ≥97 %), 1-phenylethanol (C8H10O, ≥99 %), butylated hydroxytoluene (C15H24O, ≥99 %), ethanol (C2H6O, ≥99 %), tridecane (C13H28, ≥99 %) were obtained from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. Commercial 5 wt% Pd/C, 5 wt% Ru/C, and 5 wt% Pt/C catalysts were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich company. 2-Phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (C14H14O2, ≥97 %) was obtained from Shanghai Bide Reagent Company. Ruthenium (III) chloride trihydrate (RuCl3·3H2O, ≥97 %) and RuO2·xH2O (Ru > 44 %) was supplied by Macklin Reagent Company. Carbon nanotubes (inner diameter 4∼8 nm and outer diameter 10∼20 nm) were purchased from Chengdu Organic Chemicals. Poplar wood was taken from the local and all chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation In a typical synthesis of spherical carbon supports, 40 ml 0.5 M glucose aqueous solution was put in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave with Teflon liner, and then heated at 180 °C for 6 h in an oven. Subsequently, the reddish-brown solid was filtered, washed five times with distilled water until the filtrate was clear, and then washed once with ethanol and acetone by centrifugation. After drying at 80 °C overnight, the powder was collected and calcined at various temperatures for 3 h under N2. The obtained carbon support was denoted as Cs-X, where X represents the calcination temperature. To prepare supported Ru(OH)x catalysts, 500 mg of each support was first dispersed in a 5 ml of RuCl3 aqueous solution (Ru concentration: 2 mg/ml). After stirring for 30 min and ultrasonic treatment for 1 h, the solvent was removed by rotary evaporation. Then, 1 ml of 0.5 M NaOH was added dropwise onto the above powder and stirred thoroughly to precipitate Ru(OH)x on the support. Subsequently, the catalyst was collected by centrifugation, washed five times with water, and dried in an vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) using Cu Ka radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA) in the 2θ range of 10∼80°. N2 adsorption–desorption measurement was performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 adsorption analyzer. Before the measurements, all samples were degassed at 200 °C under evacuation for 10 h. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the total pore volume was determined at a relative pressure of 0.99. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR) were recorded on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 spectrometer equipped with an attenuated total reflectance accessory. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out using an FEI Talos F200S instrument with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were captured on a Thermo Scientific Helios G4 CX microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo SCIENTIFIC Nexsa system using Al Kα monochromatic radiation. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of the catalysts was carried out on an Autochem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The conductivity and resistivity of CS-X were tested at a pressure of 30 MPa using the four-probe method on an ST2742B fully automatic powder resistivity tester. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis was conducted on an Agilent ICP-OES 725 ES to determine the loading of Ru. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was performed on a Bruker EMX-9.5/12 instrument. Due to the presence of water will affect the capture of superoxide radicals by DMPO, the test of superoxide radicals was carried out in ultra-dry methanol. Kelvin Probe Forced Microscopy (KPFM) was performed on a Shimadzu SPM-8100FM to determine the electron transfer potentials by detecting the Contact Potential Difference (CPD) between the probe tip and the sample surface in a nanoscale space. The CPD of Ru(OH)x and Cs-700 surface was calculated by the following equations: (1) CP D Cs - 700 = φ tip - φ Cs - 700 (2) CP D R u OH x = φ tip - φ R u OH x where φtip , φRu(OH)x and φCs-700 represent the work functions of probe tip, Ru(OH)x and Cs-700. The difference between the Fermi levels ( ΔEF ) of the carbon substrate and the metal active site can be determined by ΔCPD, which is defined here as: (3) Δ E F = Δ C P D = C P D Cs - 700 - C P D R u OH x The short-circuit current was measured to evaluate the electron transfer between Ru(OH)x and various supports. Various supports (working electrode) and RuO2·xH2O (counter electrode) were deposited on the surface of two glassy carbon electrodes (the electrode surface area of 0.1963 cm2), respectively. Two electrodes were introduced into the single-chamber battery solution. The current changes were recorded using the zero-resistance ammeter function of the RST electrochemical workstation (SHIRUISI, CHN) with a recording interval of 2 s. O2 and N2 were switched periodically every 20 min with a flow rate of 50 ml/min. 2.4 Catalytic reactions For the oxidative cleavage of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol, generally, 200 mg 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol, 25 mg catalyst, 75 mg NaOH and 10 ml solvent were added in a 100 ml mechanical stirring stainless steel batch-reactor with PTFE lining (Shanghai YAN ZHENG Instrument, YZPR-100 M). After sealing the reactor, the reactor was purged with oxygen for three times to replace the air, and then the oxygen was pressurized to a certain pressure. After the reaction, the reaction solution was acidified with 10 ml of 0.2 M hydrochloric acid and then extracted three times with 10 ml of ethyl acetate. The ethyl acetate phase was dried over Na2SO4 and the product was identified by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) using an Agilent 7890 A/5975C instrument equipped with an HP-5 MS column (30 m in length, 0.25 mm in diameter), and quantified by gas chromatography (GC) using a Shimadzu GC-2010 M equipped with an HP-5 column (30 m in length, 0.25 mm in diameter) and FID detector, with tridecane as the internal standard. Oxidative depolymerization of lignin was performed in the same bath-reactor. In a typical run, 500 mg poplar wood (dry basis), 50 mg catalyst and 10 ml of NaOH aqueous solution were added to the reactor. The reactor was sealed and then filled with air and pressurized to 20 bar. The reactor was heated to the desired temperature with continuous stirring. After reaction, the reactor was quenched in water and depressurized at room temperature. 5 ml of the reaction solution was acidified with 5 ml of 1 M hydrochloric acid and then extracted with 10 ml of ethyl acetate for three times. The ethyl acetate was evaporated by a rotary evaporator to obtain a brown lignin oil, to which 5 mg of tridecane was added as a standard. The quantification of the monoaromatic products was performed using the correction factor of vanillin (as the representative product) and tridecane as the internal standard. The conversion of lignin model compound and selectivity to corresponding products were defined as follows: C o n v e r s i o n ( m o l % ) = ( 1 - n A n A o ) × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y t o t h e p r o d u c t p ( m o l % ) = ( n p n A o - n A ) × 100 % n A and n A o refers to the final, initial number of the moles of model compounds, respectively. n p is the number of the moles of product p. For lignocellulose, the yield of monocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons was calculated as follows: Y i e l d ( w t . % ) = Mass monoaromatics Mass lignin × 100 % Mass monoaromatics refers to the weight of monocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons produced, where Mass lignin refers to the initial mass of lignin in lignocellulosic biomass, which was determined by the method of organic solvent extraction. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst screening In order to evaluate the oxidation activity of different metal catalysts towards β-O-4 lignin bonds, a typical lignin β-O-4 model compound 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPol) was used as the reactant [27]. The oxidation reaction was carried out in a batch reactor with water as solvent under oxygen atmosphere. Normally, the oxidation of PPol involves the dehydrogenation of Cα-OH to Cα=O, followed by CC/CO cleavage to form phenol and benzoic acid (Table 1 ) [28]. The dehydrogenation of Cα-OH to Cα=O occurs over metal catalysts, while the cleavage of Cα-Cβ usually occurs in the presence of a base such as NaOH [29]. Considering that oxidation of Cα-OH to Cα=O is the key step in the oxidative depolymerization of lignin, first, the commercial carbon-supported Pd, Ru and Pt catalysts with a metal loading of 5 wt% were tested in the oxidation of PPol at 120 °C and 5 bar oxygen in the absence of NaOH (Table 1, entries 1–3). The PPol conversion over Ru/C was 43.5 %, which was higher than that of Pd/C (41.4 %) and Pt/C (16.6 %), suggesting the high oxidation activity of Ru. Due to the lack of base, the dehydrogenation product 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanone (PPo) was the major product in all tested metal catalysts. To promote the cleavage of PPo, NaOH was added to the reaction mixture and used as a co-catalyst. As expected, the major products shifted to phenol and benzoic acid over these metal catalysts, confirming the promoting effect of NaOH on the cleavage of PPo. Interestingly, Ru/C still gave the highest conversion of PPol (58.7 %) and the highest selectivity to phenol (46.2 %) and benzoic acid (52.1 %), demonstrating the excellent oxidation activity of Ru/C (Table 1, entries 4–6) [30]. No conversion of PPol was observed in the absence of metal catalysts, indicating the key role of metal catalysts in the dehydrogenation of PPol (Table 1, entry 7). Notably, GC–MS analysis shows that only PPo, phenol and benzoic acid are detected in the PPol oxidation reactions, and no other by-products are detected, suggesting the high selectivity of this reaction (Fig. S2). Therefore, through catalysts screening, Ru/C showed the best oxidation activity for β-O-4 lignin linkages and was selected for subsequent studies. It was supposed that metallic Ru nanoparticles on Ru/C will transfer to Ru(OH)x in an oxidative hydrothermal condition. To confirm this, commercial Ru/C catalyst was subjected to H2-TPR analysis before and after oxidative hydrothermal treatment (Fig. S1). The significant increase of H2 consumption of Ru/C after treatment confirmed the in-situ oxidation of metallic Ru nanoparticles to its oxide forms. It also has been previously reported that the oxidized Ru (e.g. RuO2 and Ru(OH)x) is the active component for alcohol oxidation reactions [31]. Based on these insights, Ru(OH)x supported on different supports such as SiO2, Al2O3 and TiO2 (∼1.85 wt% metal loading) were prepared by a co-precipitation method using NaOH as precipitant and RuCl3 as metal precursors (Table S1, entries 1–3). The various metal oxides supported Ru(OH)x catalysts were employed in the oxidation of PPol to investigate the effect of support on the reaction performance. However, a significant lower PPol conversion on metal oxides supported Ru(OH)x compared with that on Ru/C was observed either in the presence or absence of NaOH (Table 1, entries 8–13). For example, Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 and Ru(OH)x/TiO2 have been extensively reported as highly active catalysts for alcohol oxidation reactions [32]. However, in aqueous phase, Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 merely gave an 7.8 % conversion of PPol in the absence of NaOH and a 7.1 % conversion of PPol in the presence of NaOH. Similarly, only 4.1 % and 12.1 % conversion of PPol were observed on Ru(OH)x/TiO2 catalyst with and without NaOH, respectively. These results indicate that the carbon supports promote the oxidation activity of Ru(OH)x in aqueous phase. To further verify the promotion effect of carbon supports, a carbon supported Ru(OH)x catalyst named as Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst was prepared by the same co-precipitation method (Table S1, entry 10). The carbon support was prepared by a hydrothermal treatment of glucose in an autoclave and then calcination at 700 °C under nitrogen atmosphere, which has a spherical morphology (Fig. S3). As expected, the Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst still exhibited high PPol oxidation activity either in the presence or absence of NaOH (Table 1, entries 14–15), confirming the superiority of carbon support over metal oxides in this reaction. It has been reported that Ru(OH)x supported on metal oxides exhibited high activity in the aerobic oxidation of various kinds of structurally diverse alcohols in toluene solvent [19,24]. In order to compare with the previous reports, we carried out the oxidation of PPol in toluene solvent over various supported Ru(OH)x catalysts under the same reaction conditions (100 °C and 2 bar O2). As shown in Fig. 2 , all the catalysts in toluene solvent showed almost similar PPol conversions ranging from 10∼14 %, with the main product is PPo due to the absence of NaOH. Interestingly, when the reactions were performed in water solvent under same reaction conditions, Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 demonstrated exceptional high activity with a PPol conversion enhanced to 46.1 %, while other metal oxides supported Ru(OH)x still showed PPol conversion less than 20 %. Furthermore, to check the promoting effect of Ru(OH)x catalyst for other lignin model compounds in aqueous phase, 1,2-diphenylethanol (β-1 linkage lignin model compound) and methoxy-containing β-O-4 model compounds were investigated under the same reaction conditions. The carbon supported catalyst still showed high β-H elimination activity in the aqueous phase (Fig. S4). Such phenomena suggested that water could somehow promoted the alcohol oxidation reaction over carbon supported Ru(OH)x catalyst. To further explore how carbon support promotes the oxidation activity of Ru(OH)x in the aqueous phase, other carbon materials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphite powder have been used as supports. According to characterizations (Table S1, entries 4–5), these three carbon supported catalysts (Ru(OH)x/CNTs, Ru(OH)x/graphite, and Ru(OH)x/Cs-700) have significantly different surface area and pore structure. In particular, the BET surface area of Ru(OH)x/graphite is merely 22.1 m2/g, showing a condensed structure with little amount of porosity (Table S1, entry 5). However, both Ru(OH)x/CNTs and Ru(OH)x/graphite exhibited high activity in the aqueous phase PPol oxidation reactions with a conversion of 48.9 % and 52.9 %, respectively (Table 1, entries 16–17). Regardless of the vast difference in surface area and porosity, all the carbon supports used here are expected to be conductive. Therefore, it is speculated that the electrical conductivity of the carbon support played an important role in promoting the oxidation activity of Ru(OH)x in the aqueous phase. To confirm this hypothesis, carbon spheres (Cs) prepared from glucose were calcined at different temperatures (400∼1000 °C) under nitrogen atmosphere to tune the degree of graphitization, thus to control the conductivity of the carbon matrix [33]. Extensive characterizations including XRD, BET, FTIR and Raman spectroscopy were conducted to analyze the structural evolution of Cs-X supports upon calcination at different temperatures, where X represents the calcination temperature (Fig. S5). It was suggested that upon the calcination temperature increase, three kinds of structural changes occurred on the carbon sphere. First, the graphitization degree of the carbon sphere increased. Second, the surface oxygen groups gradually eliminated. And finally, the surface area of the carbon sphere first increased from 13.3 m2/g by calcination at 400 °C to 393.8 m2/g by calcination at 700 °C, and then decreased to 135.9 m2/g by calcination at 1000 °C. Normally, with the increase of graphitization degree of carbon material, its electrical conductivity will also increase. As expected, the electrical conductivity of Cs-X measured by a four-contact method (25 °C and 30 MPa) suggested that the conductivity enhanced upon the increase of calcination temperature (Fig. 3 a). The catalytic activities of Ru(OH)x/Cs-X catalysts were tested. As shown in Fig. 3a, with the increase of calcination temperature from 400 to 700 °C, the conversion of PPol increased simultaneously from 5.2 % to 55.3 %. Further increase the calcination temperate to 1000 °C resulted in slightly decrease of PPol conversion from 55.3 % to 50.1 %. It seems that the tendency of PPol conversion over Ru(OH)x/Cs-X catalysts is similar to the changes of BET surface area. However, the BET surface area is definitely not the detrimental factor for the superior oxidation activity of carbon supported Ru(OH)x catalysts. For example, Ru(OH)x/SiO2 have a higher BET surface area than Ru(OH)x/Cs-1000 catalyst (162.5 vs. 135.9 m2/g), however, Ru(OH)x/Cs-1000 catalyst exhibited almost four times higher activity than Ru(OH)x/SiO2 (12.8 vs. 50.1 %). Another evidence is that the Ru(OH)x/graphite with extremely low BET surface area (22.1 m2/g) possessed exceptional high oxidation activity (PPol conv. 52.9 %). Although the BET surface area is not the key factor affecting the oxidation activity of Ru(OH)x/Cs-X catalyst, a higher BET surface area improves the dispersion of Ru(OH)x species, which can explain the slight decrease in PPol conversion when the calcination temperature is further increased from 700 to 1000 °C. Therefore, based on the extensive catalytic and characterization results, it is concluded that carbon supports can significantly promote the oxidation activity of Ru(OH)x in the aqueous phase oxidation of PPol, which is attributed to the electrical conductivity of the carbon matrix. The reusability of the Ru(OH)x catalyst has also been studied by five consequent reaction cycles at moderate PPol conversion in the presence of base (Fig. 3b). After each reaction, the catalyst was centrifuged, washed, and reused without drying. The conversion of PPol and the selectivity to phenol and benzoic acid have almost not change, demonstrating the high stability of Ru(OH)x/C catalyst. 3.2 Mechanistic studies In order to explore how the conductivity of carbon affects the oxidation activity of Ru(OH)x, the Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst was subjected to further characterizations. As evidenced by TEM images (Fig. 4 a–g), Ru(OH)x species are evenly distributed on the surface of carbon spheres, with flat shapes and particle sizes ranging from 2∼3 nm (Fig. 4a &b). Meanwhile, the elemental mapping analysis indicates that Ru and O elements are located on the same place, confirming that Ru presents in the oxide forms (Fig. 4c–g). Ru 3p XPS has two components of 3p1/2 (485.8 eV) and 3p3/2 (463.7 eV) with 22.1 eV spin–orbit splitting, respectively (Fig. 4h), attributing to the RuO2 species, which is generated by the dehydration of Ru(OH)x. O 1s XPS also demonstrated the presence of Ru oxide on the catalyst surface, where the O 1s binding energy of the Ru-O species is 529.7 eV (Fig. 4i) [34]. C 1s XPS suggested the co-existence of sp3 and sp2 hybridized carbon species, confirming the formation of graphite domains on the surface (Fig. 4j). It is noteworthy that Fig. S6 shows the survey scan of the Ru(OH)x/Cs-X catalyst, indicating that these catalysts do not contain chlorine, ruling out the influence of other elements on the reaction. It was reported that the oxidation of HMF to FDCA in aqueous phase was favored by accelerating the charge transfer through the integration of Au/C and Pd/C catalyst [35]. Pd/C is responsible for HMF dehydrogenation while Au/C is responsible for molecular oxygen activation. The entire catalytic cycle is achieved with the assistance of a conductive carbon matrix, which enables electron transfer from Pd nanoparticles to Au nanoparticles. Inspired by the pioneering work, we suspected that the excellent oxidation activity of Ru(OH)x/C in aqueous phase might be due to the charge transfer between Ru(OH)x and the carbon, where Ru(OH)x is responsible for the oxidation of alcohols and carbon is responsible for the reduction of molecular oxygen. To examine the potential electron transfer between metal and support, PPol was catalytically oxidized by physical mixing of RuO2 and various supports (Fig. S7). RuO2 itself can catalyze the oxidation of PPol to mainly PPo with a conversion of 43.8 %. Addition of metal oxides such as TiO2, SiO2 and Al2O3 to the reaction mixture had negligible promotion effects on the oxidation activity. Surprisingly, the addition of conductive carbon supports such as Cs-700 and graphite increased the PPol conversion from 43.8 % to 78.8 % and 85.8 %, respectively. It is noteworthy that only carbon cannot catalyze the reaction, indicating that the existence of charge transfer between Ru(OH)x and conductive carbon promotes the oxidation activity. To further prove that electron transfer between Ru(OH)x and Cs-700, Kelvin Probe Force Microscope (KPFM) was used to detect the Contact Potential Difference (CPD) between the probe tip and the sample surface in nanoscale space [36]. The topographic images and surface potential distribution of Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 are shown in Fig. 5 a & b. When the probe moved along A1-A3 marked in Fig. 5b, it was observed that the potential of A1-A3 fluctuated greatly, demonstrating a 74 mV CPD difference between Ru(OH)x and Cs-700 (Fig. 5c). The higher Fermi level of Cs-700 than that of Ru(OH)x favors the electron transfer from electron-rich Ru(OH)x to electron-deficient carbon support (Fig. 5d) [37]. The critical role of electron transfer between Ru(OH)x and carbon was further investigated by electrochemistry. The experiments were performed in a single-chamber cell by externally short-circuiting the RuO2 and Cs-700 electrodes (Fig. 6 a). 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural, which has high water solubility, was used as the probe molecule. Under N2 flow, no current was detected, demonstrating that there was no electron transfer between RuO2 and the carbon support. In the presence of O2, the current from Cs-700 to RuO2 was observed, indicating that HMF donated electrons to RuO2, while O2 took electrons from Cs-700 (Fig. 6b). This phenomenon can only be observed when carbon was used as electrodes. With the introduction of O2, the current gradually decreases, which is due to the saturation of HMF on the catalyst surface, blocking the active sites and preventing further reactions [35]. Previous studies have shown that carbon-based materials (graphite or disordered carbon) can activate oxygen for metal-free oxidation reactions, in which molecular oxygen abstracts electrons from the conductive carbon matrix to form superoxide radicals (•O2 –) [38,39]. To further elucidate how electron circulate in the reaction and to investigate the reaction mechanism, free radical trapping experiments were performed. Compared with the slight inhibition after the addition of isopropanol and tert-butyl alcohol, ascorbic acid and p-benzoquinone showed very strong inhibition, indicating that superoxide radicals rather than hydroxyl radicals play a key role in the reaction (Fig. 7 a). EPR analysis was further performed to identify the free radical species involved in the reaction (Fig. 7b). Only Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 showed the typical EPR signals corresponding to the DMPO-·O2 – adducts, and other metal oxides supported Ru(OH)x catalysts (e.g., SiO2, Al2O3, and TiO2) did not show the presence of •O2 –. Even for pure RuO2, non-radicals were observed based on EPR analysis. These results are consistent with previous reports that free radicals do not participate in the oxidation of alcohols over RuO2/Al2O3 catalysts. However, in this case, both free radical trapping experiments and EPR analysis confirmed that free radicals (e.g. superoxide radicals) were involved in the oxidation of PPol on carbon supported Ru(OH)x catalysts in aqueous phase. The elimination of β-H by Ru with the generation of Ru-H is a key step in conventional alcohol oxidation reactions over Ru(OH)x catalysts [24]. In order to check the generation of Ru-H species on Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst during PPol oxidation, transfer hydrogenation of acetophenone by isopropanol was performed over Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 and Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 7c & d), respectively [23]. In pure isopropanol solvent, both Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 and Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 catalyzed the transfer hydrogen reaction, indicating that Ru-H was formed in the organic phase. However, in the presence of water, the transfer hydrogen reaction was completely blocked over the Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst, suggesting that Ru-H cannot be formed over the Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst in the presence of water. Under the same reaction conditions, Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 still exhibited a comparable acetophenone conversion of 11 %, indicating that Ru-H intermediates can be formed on the Ru(OH)x/Al2O3 catalyst. These experiments indicate that it is difficult for Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst to form Ru-H species in aqueous phase, and thus it is speculated that Ru-H intermediates do not participate in the oxidation of PPol on Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst in aqueous phase. Based on mechanistic studies, a novel aqueous-phase Ru(OH)x-catalyzed alcohol oxidation pathway is proposed (Fig. 8 ). First, molecular oxygen takes electrons from the conductive carbon matrix to form superoxide radicals (•O2 –), which then react with water to form HOO• radicals. At the same time, the alcohol dehydrates with the Ru-OH species (Ⅰ) to form Ru-alkoxide intermediate (Ⅱ). Then, the β-H is eliminated by HOO• to generate H2O2 along with the formation of a carbon-centered free radical intermediate (Ⅲ). Finally, intermediate Ⅲ is hydrolyzed by water to regenerate to the initial state, and the electrons are transferred from the alcohol to Ru, eventually compensating to the conductive carbon matrix. Notably, the formation of H2O2 during the reaction was confirmed by hydrogen peroxide test paper (Fig. S8). And the conversion of PPol on Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 was indeed greatly suppressed when using butyl hydroxytoluene (BHT) as carbon-centered free radical scavenger (Fig. 6b), confirming the existence of intermediate Ⅲ [40]. 3.3 Oxidative depolymerization of real lignin To demonstrate the feasibility of Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst for the oxidative depolymerization of lignin in aqueous phase, native poplar wood was used as a substrate. The lignin content of poplar sawdust was determined to be 29.0 wt.% by an organic solvent extraction method. Due to the inherent rigidity of the real lignin structure, high temperatures (typically ≥ 160 °C) and alkaline conditions are usually required to promote lignin dissociation and maximize monomer yield [14]. Thus, the oxidative depolymerization reaction was carried out at 160 °C with air as the oxidant and 1 M NaOH aqueous solution as the solvent. As it is shown in Fig. 9 , without addition of metal catalyst, only small amount of monoaromatic products with a total yield of 4.3 wt.% were produced. This phenomenon is consistent with previous reports that lignin can be partially oxidatively depolymerized by NaOH [41,42]. After the addition of Ru(OH)x catalysts, the yield of monoaromatics improved as expected. Interestingly, compared to the metal oxide supported Ru(OH)x catalyst, the carbon supported Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 showed the highest yield of monoaromatic products (14.5 wt.%), confirming that the free-radical induced β-H elimination does indeed promote the oxidative cleavage of real lignin. In addition, to eliminate the influence of the inherent wax in lignocellulose on the oxidative depolymerization of lignin, poplar sawdust was first subjected to wax extraction and then underwent oxidative depolymerization. The results are presented in Fig. S9. The oxidative depolymerization of dewaxed poplar catalyzed by Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 yielded 14.1 wt.% of monoaromatic products, which is comparable to the depolymerization amount of native poplar. As indicated by GC–MS analysis (Fig. S10), the main monoaromatic products are syringaldehyde, vanillin acid, acetovanillone and vanillin. It is noteworthy that the Ru(OH)x/Cs-700 catalyst exhibits the highest yield of vanillin (4.5 wt.%), a versatile spice utilized in the food industry. This highlights the significant potential for the high-value utilization of lignin through oxidation in the future. 4 Conclusions In this study, a novel reaction mechanism for aqueous-phase alcohol oxidation over a Ru(OH)x catalyst was proposed. In contrast with the conventional reaction mechanism, whereby Ru abstracts β-H from alcohol, forming Ru-H, our findings demonstrate that carbon-supported Ru(OH)x oxidizes the alcohols by a free-radical induced β-H elimination mechanism, without the formation of Ru-H. In this case, the Ru(OH)x is accountable for dehydrogenating α-H and taking electron from the alcohol, whereas the carbon support is responsible for donating electron to oxygen to form superoxide radicals and acts as a bridge for electron cycling. The afore mentioned reaction mechanism facilitates the efficient oxidative depolymerization of lignin in an aqueous phase. A 14.5 wt.% total yield of monoaromatic products including 4.5 wt.% yield of vanillin was obtained in aqueous phase oxidation of native polar wood by carbon-supported Ru(OH)x catalyst. The findings of this study contribute to the advancement of knowledge regarding alcohol oxidations over supported metal catalysts, which will prove beneficial for the development of more efficient oxidation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidative depolymerization of lignin is an important strategy for producing valuable oxygen-functionalized monoaromatic compounds. However, this process is less efficient over heterogeneous catalysts due to the slow rate-determining step of selective oxidation of secondary alcohol (Cα-OH to Cα=O) in β-O-4 lignin linkages. Herein, a facile and efficient Ru(OH)x/C catalyst was developed for the oxidative depolymerization of lignin model compounds and real lignin in aqueous phase using molecular oxygen as oxidant. Extensive characterizations revealed that molecular oxygen abstracts electrons from the conductive carbon matrix to generate superoxide radicals (•O2 –), which are subsequently converted to hydroperoxide radicals (HOO•) in the presence of water. The Cα-OH in the β-O-4 linkages first reacts with Ru-OH to form a Ru-O-C(H)- metal alkoxide intermediate, which then undergoes β-H elimination with the help of HOO• to generate H2O2 and surface Ru-O-C•- species. Hydrolysis of Ru-O-C•- leads to the generation of Cα=O products and the regeneration of Ru-OH sites. Different from the traditional Ru(OH)x-catalyzed alcohol dehydration mechanism in which Ru abstracts β-H to form Ru-H, in this case, the β-H in the Ru-alkoxide intermediate is eliminated by the hydroperoxide radicals rather than Ru, avoiding the formation of inert Ru-H species, thereby accelerating the dehydrogenation of Cα-OH to Cα=O. Electrochemical measurements further confirmed the charge transfer from Ru(OH)x to carbon during alcohol oxidation, demonstrating that electron donation by alcohol occurs on Ru(OH)x, while electron abstraction by O2 occurs on the carbon. The free-radical-involved β-H elimination reaction pathway endows Ru(OH)x/C with superior catalytic oxidation activity in the aqueous phase compared with traditional metal oxides supported Ru(OH)x (e.g. SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2), and provides a fundamental basis for the rational design of aqueous phase oxidation catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Radical-induced β-H elimination through metal-support charge transfer in Ru(OH)x/C catalyst for enhanced lignin oxidative depolymerization in aqueous phase
